title: What will be the closing value for the Dow Jones Transportation Average on 30 August 2019?
preds: 'Choppy' markets lately. DJTA is up now...
Looking like too much bad news/'erratic policy-making' right now:  https://www.marketwatch.com/story/stock-futures-seesaw-as-investors-gauge-trade-fight-economic-data-2019-08-27

Despite Donald Trump's various 'antics'  the DJTA has spent the majority of August above the 10000 level. 
We'll see what next week brings.... https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/TRAN:IND
10,107 - Markets expecting supportive statement fron FED on Friday.

There is no rational handrail that can predict where the US market will be in an hour, let alone on a specific day later this month.  Options trading tidal flows (and Possible Plunge protection futures trading syndicates) are blowing heavy intoxicating smoke through the market. The key word being toxic. So many critical pillars have been removed from the economic scaffolding in the past year or so that comparing our markets to musical chairs entails a haunting faith that there are still any chairs left in the room now.  Of course corrupt policies will still eek out a few blockbuster short term fist bumps.    Robots, and their currencies seem to be right around the corner, just a question of which corner.

The 3-month chart looks bad. 
The 5-day looks steady, but still is drifting south.
Daily close < 10,000 would be bad news bears.
10,148.  Trump tweets threatens trade, markets down.  Trump tweets benefits trade, markets up.
The industry press keeps referring to a Transportation recession and its effect Truck/Rail/River traffic.

Waiting for the Plunge Protection Team.
From: https://www.investopedia.com/terms/p/plunge-protection-team.asp
"Though not exactly a secret, the Plunge Protection Team isn't widely covered and doesn't release the minutes of its meetings or its recommendations, reporting only to the president. This behavior leads some observers to wonder if the government's most important financial officials are doing more than analyzing and advising—in fact, that are actively intervening in the markets.
"Conspiracy theorists have speculated that the group execute trades on several exchanges when prices are heading downward, collaborating with big banks such as Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley in unrecorded transactions. They often point to a 1989 speech published in The Wall Street Journal by former Federal Reserve Board of Governors member Robert Heller, which suggested the Fed could directly support the stock market by purchasing index futures contracts."
based upon historical price changes for August with a bias towards pre-election year performance
There is an base upward trend since 2015. Read briefly that djta is expected to follow djia, which is rising this year. I forecast it can rise.

7/30/19: In the past few days the DJTA July % increase has passed the percent increase of the Dow Jones Industrial Avg. (this month), likely in part from a run-up in the price of (DJTA component) United Parcel Svc.  .. That may not be sustainable: https://www.marketwatch.com/story/ups-stock-falls-after-analyst-says-post-earnings-surge-raises-concern-about-12-month-upside-2019-07-29 (Ref.:)  https://www.marketwatch.com/story/ups-stock-soars-toward-best-gain-in-a-decade-after-profit-beat-outlook-held-firm-2019-07-24 https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/TRAN:IND
due to automation and matt manero in texas announcing the trucking business over these last 7 months has been weak

Though rate cut might incentivise the US economy and S&P index. But just for a short period, Based on fundamental analysis, CSX's poor performence reflects a weaker domestic demand thorugh our this year. Furthuer more giving the uncertainties of US and China trade war or US trade war againt all other countries. It is safe to say that giving the index a more bearish prediction is quite resonable.

(FWIW:) DJT generally rising over the past month or so..."catching up" with the DJIA. https://www.marketwatch.com/story/one-of-these-leading-economic-gauges-isnt-telling-the-truth-2019-07-12 https://www.forecasts.org/djtrans.htm

Markets are performing positively, the big guys are friends again.

Two months left for this challenge.  The DJ Transports did well over the last few days.  Since it is smack in the middle of the 10k-11k range, I'm favoring that it stays there.  But things could change, so I'll watch it closely.

Maintaining a generally "neutral" DJT forecast outlook, for now. https://realmoney.thestreet.com/investing/stocks/high-vap-level-turning-from-resistance-to-support-14995882 https://seekingalpha.com/news/3472864-airline-stocks-miss-rally-grounded-rising-oil-prices
If all stays the same thats were we will be

So I was headed north out of Little Rock yesterday after a VA visit. All my life I have not seen the Arkansas River that high and fast. It was swallowing a park near the Clinton Presidential Horse Trailer , and was completely swamping it in the time it took to drive across the bridge. I tell that story to add gravitas when i say that the Agricultural end of the transportation industry is being upended. Planting Prevention Ins. Claims are record. River Rail and Road - all compromised thru one of the busiest E-W corridors in the nation. If the crops are in - they won't be, and won't need the million of tons of hauling capacity to supply them with fertilizer, chemicals, and transport after Harvest. This isn't anecdotal - its a systemic description.

Update of monthly time-series forecast using R function 'forecast' from package of the same name. The algorithm selects exponential smoothing in this case, and the point forecast for the end of August is 10,014.

Will the crowd learn from the recent Bitcoin experience? Daily prices are feedback/fact we can only dream of in other questions, yet forecasters suffer the same cognitive biases as investors. Fascinating!

https://www.marketwatch.com/story/stock-futures-tumble-as-trump-slaps-tariffs-against-all-imports-from-mexico-2019-05-30 A 'relief rally' of some sort may still be possible if tariffs are eased/eliminated down the road..

Oops!  GJ wouldn't let me insert tabs to set up columns for the company weightings.  I copied and pasted from a spreadsheet, which I used to sort the data.  It saved my predictions before I could change the weightings. Note that the top 5 companies comprise 44% of the index, while the bottom 5 only represent about 10%.  The top 5 include the two big parcel delivery companies, one trucker, and two railroads.  All of the companies in the index are deep cyclicals.  Since we are late in the business cycle by most economists' thinking it's unlikely that they will race ahead.  Unlikely, but of course possible.

If you want to do a bottom up analysis of the transport index here are the company weightings: <https://www.money-zine.com/investing/stocks/dow-jones-transportation/> With 110 days left in this challenge I'm downshifting from favoring 11k-12k to favoring 10k-11k. last year: 15,63,22,0.
Took the average of those two. Adjusting base rate up to higher buckets due to @Emil 's and @ulfelder 's forecasts. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/858257 https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/855962

Update of monthly algorithmic forecast using 'forecast' function in R package of same name on end-of-month time series downloaded from FRED. Algo selected an exponential smoothing model with multiplicative trend. Current point forecast for end of August is 11,092.
The trend seems to be upward for the past 5 years. 11303 last August.

Outside view: Using historical information (i.e. historical daily movements and standard deviation from the last 10 years) to build a Random Walk/Monte Carlo model. These are unadjusted results from same: 12, 22, 27, 40. Inside view:  I am adjusting somewhat to take into account results from ARIMA-type model used by @ulfelder. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/854263 ARIMA type models (aka time series models) capture any trends that might exist in the short term. While I assume that stocks follow random walks with drift over the long term, I don't exclude the possibility of short term dependencies and trends, hence I account for @ulfelder's results. There are also a number economic red flags such as the 3-10 yield curve inversion that the stock market is bucking for one reason or another [1] which suggest stocks may be too high right now for fundamentals, implying a possible trip back down (to Earth?).  [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2019/04/24/business/dealbook/stock-market-high.html

Market growth remains relatively stable a world economic rebalance will occur in the future and disrupt this over the coming years.  Low unemployment, more manufacturing jobs in the US, and U.S. cloing in on energy independence.

Airlines and rail will take the average back to its 12 month high.  After August there may be a retreat back to the mid to high 10,000s but there is enough momentum in the economy to take us through a strong Summer.

Goods and people are moving more all the time. The trend has been upwards on this index, and while there is the chance of a correction, my gut feel is that it will continue upwards for some time before that occurs.
recent (5 year) history of this index

The time period for this challenge is short, only a little over 4 months to go.  The current level of the Dow Jones Transportation Average is 10,988, so we are essentially at the boundary between two target ranges.  In the short term the market is volatile -- 10% up or down can happen quickly.  Long term the bias is generally up.  I'm going to put the highest probability (51%) at 11,000 to 12,000, with the second most likely outcome at 10,000 to 11,000 (31%).  I'll guess (that's really all it is) that the likelihood of a melt up is greater than for a melt down, so 11% for greater than 12,000 and 7% for under 10,000.

Forecast based on some scenarios run based on historic performance and resistance in the region of 11,400 points (16% - 52% - 32%- 0%). The DJTA includes airlines, transportation (marine, railroads, trucking) and delivery services. Historic performance doesn't need to explain future behaviour so I tried with other indicator like Brent and got a strong direct correlation from Jan 1st 2018 (which means that either my data and/or calculations are wrong or that there is no causality). My assumption was that higher oil price should impact the stock prices of the companies included on the index, but couldn't see that. Still, oil should be an indicator, if only due to phycological reasons. Short term price most likely will go up: "What is today’s oil market telling us? opec agreed in December to cut production. Demand is picking up. The spot price has risen from $53 to $70 a barrel since the start of the year. The market may well tighten further in the short term. Saudi Arabia, opec’s largest producer, is pumping less than its quota; it seems keen on higher prices. Meanwhile foreign-policy hawks in America want to tighten the screws on Iran’s oil exports. Power cuts in oil-rich but inflation-ravaged Venezuela have further reduced its capacity to pump oil." [1] Let's say the impact is -5 points to the 11K to 12K range. Macro data in the short term seems favourable (no recession on sight before August 30th as per my own estimate, strong performance of services [2]) at least for a few months. I add +10 points to the 11K to 12K range, given we are now very close to the 11K mark. Airlines business is having some issues: - Main one, in my opinion, the Boeing 737 MAX crashes (Southwest, American and United reported as 737 MAX major customers [3]). This might limit number of routes, revenue generation and efficiencies. Seeking compensation from Boeing will go further than August 30th.
- Jet Airways, WOW and maybe Norwegian's problems. Opportunities for all carriers or just low-cost ones?
- A curiosity, or an indicator: in-flight entertainment [4]. No impact short term, but tough competition is mentioned.
- Another one: flight attendants routes [5], no impact either, but also interesting. Over all, -7.5% 11K to 12K. Little data on other business in the DJTA. Data downloaded from here:
https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/%5EDJT/history?p=%5EDJT
https://www.macrotrends.net/2480/brent-crude-oil-prices-10-year-daily-chart [1] https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2019/04/04/how-betting-on-oil-prices-greases-the-industrys-wheels
[2] https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2019/04/04/the-gloom-hanging-over-the-world-economy-is-confined-to-manufacturing
[3] https://www.businessinsider.es/airlines-that-fly-the-boeing-737-max-2018-11?r=US&IR=T
[4] https://www.economist.com/gulliver/2019/02/27/american-carriers-are-again-competing-over-in-flight-entertainment
[5] https://www.economist.com/gulliver/2019/04/05/should-flight-attendants-be-allowed-to-sell-their-seniority

A few quick, initial observations: 
 - The DJTA has not closed above the 12,000 level in at least the last 10 years. Highest daily close I could find (during that period)  was 11,570.84 on 9/14/18. (https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DJTA#0) -- Current 52-week index range reported is  8,636.79-11,623.58 (https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/TRAN:IND) -- Over one year the index's 200-day simple moving average displays a modest increase in closing value. The index is currently above both its 50- and 200-day SMA. (..Closing last at 10,988.22 USD.) The 50-day SMA reflects more of the index's recent volatility. (https://www.marketwatch.com/investing/index/djt/charts) -- One of the most prominently-featured (via Google search) analyst forecast/analysis located seems to be generally positive on the DJT's overall prospects: ...Notes that the DJT and DJI outlooks currently appear to be "in synch", and (also that) "...transportation industry performance suggests no recession is imminent." (https://seekingalpha.com/article/4252658-transports-show-recession-threat)
Forecast generated using 'forecast' function from R package of the same name, based on monthly (last close) data downloaded from FRED ( https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/DJTA#0).
